refnamediv.refpurpose: Component responsible for selecting next observations. It either select next observations from user supplied and filled queues, from plan entries loaded from the database, or selected autonomously from available targets.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: &dhpackage; is a RTS2 component, which provides target selection services to the rts2-executor7. It suggest which targets shoudl be observed. It is up to rts2-executor (or a script running observations) to take those suggestions into account and observe targets the selector suggests.
The &dhpackage; can select next observations from those sources:

listitem.para: User named list of observations targets. Queues holds a list of targets, and select among those targets from various criteria. More is described in rts2.queues5.

Plan entries, e.g. observations which should be observed on given time, can be loaded to the queue. Planned observations are special case of queue selection. Please see rts2-plan1 for description of plan entries management tool.

Entries from queues are executed iregardless if the target is enabled or not. This allows observers to specify what they exactly want to observe, and do not worry about details that the target is currently disabled, have low priority or does not fit some constraints.

This selection runs the autonomous selection. It select among eneabled targets. The best target is selected as next target. The best target is target which have highest bonus parameter. Please see rts2-targetinfo1 for details how to obtain target bonus.

refsect1.title: Tutorial
refsect1.para: In this section is described a tutorial how to configure and use &dhpackage;. It assumes three distinct queues will be created, and user wants to observer targets created with rts2-newtarget1. The tutorial is indended for new rts21 users. Advanced users will find more valuable to read various scheduling related papers produced by RTS2 authors.
To start with, a standard installation is assumed. In particular, RTS2 must be build with database support, and the database must be up, running and configured for RTS2 devices.

refsect2.title: Target creation
refsect2.para: New targets can be best created with rts2-newtarget1. Other methods, such as direct creation in the RTS2 database, will not be discussed in this tutorial.

Lets assume we would like to add all Messier objects, from M1 to M104. This can be either done manually:
&prompt; rts2-newtarget -f -a M1 Created target #1000 named M1 on J2000.0 coordinates 05:34:31.971 +22:00:52.06 horizontal -04 30 55.25 232 21 28.67 &prompt; rts2-newtarget -f -a M2 Created target #1001 named M2 on J2000.0 coordinates 21:33:27.012 -00:49:23.94 horizontal +44 10 33.20 359 34 36.08 ... &prompt; rts2-newtarget -f -a M104 Created target #1103 named M104 on J2000.0 coordinates 12:40:00.000 -11:37:23.00 horizontal -38 12 00.40 115 06 36.48
or in a bash script:
&prompt; for ((x=1;$x < 105; x=$x + 1)); do rts2-newtarget -f -a M$x; done Created target #1000 named M1 on J2000.0 coordinates 05:34:31.971 +22:00:52.06 horizontal -04 30 55.25 232 21 28.67 Created target #1001 named M2 on J2000.0 coordinates 21:33:27.012 -00:49:23.94 horizontal +44 10 33.20 359 34 36.08 .... Created target #1103 named M104 on J2000.0 coordinates 12:40:00.000 -11:37:23.00 horizontal -38 12 00.40 115 06 36.48 &prompt;

refsect2.title: Manipulating target - priority, scripting
refsect2.para: You can skip this section, if you want to rely on the queue scheduling. Please read on, if you want to do queue scheduling with merit function scheduling as backup.

In order to assign targets priorities, and enabled them for merit function scheduling, rts2-target1 should be used. -p option specify target priority, -e option enables target for merit function selection. Multiple targets names can be specified on with a single command call. Either target names or target IDs can be used.
&prompt; rts2-target -p 100 -e M1 M2 M31 2014-03-11T18:10:18.652 CET rts2-target 4 Enable target ID 1000 (M1) 2014-03-11T18:10:18.652 CET rts2-target 4 Enable target ID 1001 (M1) 2014-03-11T18:10:18.652 CET rts2-target 4 Enable target ID 1030 (M31)
Please be aware, that the command will not print lines for already enabled targets.

Each target can have associated an observing script. RTS2 supports various scripts, from a simple on to complex one involving autofocusing and more. Please consult rts2.script5 for details. Scripts runs on cameras. In the following example, we will assign script to take 5, 10 and 20 second exposure to target 1000:
&prompt; rts2-target -c C0 -s 'E 5 E 10 E 20' 100

refsect2.title: Verifying target settings
refsect2.para: After targets are prepared for observation, it is good to check that the setting match what one expect. This can be achieved with rts2-targetinfo1 command. As is the case with rts2-target1 command, the arguments can be either target names, or target IDs. In case target names and IDs are not know, list of all targets present in the database can be obtained with rts2-targetlist1 command.

To obtain information about target M31, use the following command:
&prompt; rts2-targetinfo -e M31 ID 1000 SEL_ID 1000 NAME M31 TYPE O .... 24 HOURS OBS 0 7 DAYS OBS 0 BONUS 192.165909 Target is above local horizon. Target is enabled
IS VISIBLE TONIGHT yes
TARGET PRIORITY 100.000000 TARGET BONUS 0.000000 TARGET BONUS TIME 1970-01-01T01:00:00.000 CET TARGET NEXT OBS. 1970-01-01T01:00:00.000 CET
The important lines are:
BONUS 192.165909
Current value of the target merit function. The value will change over time, as the formula includes various time-dependent values.
IS VISIBLE TONIGHT yes
Target is visible during night. Targets which are not visible shall not be, for a obvious reason, observed.
TARGET PRIORITY 100.000000
Priority of the target.
TARGET BONUS 100.000000
Target bonus. Target merit function is calculated as a sum of target priority, target bonus and time-dependant part.

refsect2.title: Verifying target selection algorithm
refsect2.para:
After preparing database with targets for night observation, it is handy to verify which targets will be selected with merit function. This can be achived through rts2-seltest1 command. Best is to run it with --print-possible parameter, as is described bellow:
&prompt; rts2-seltest --print-possible List of targets selected for observations. Sort from the one with the highest priority to lowest priorities
1 329.45 100.00 1000 O 00:42:44.350 +41:16:08.63 -02:25 1.12 +63 23 22.34 265 02 19.56 rising M31 2 188.75 0.00 1002 O 21:33:27.012 -00:49:23.94 +00:43 1.46 +43 09 57.42 015 01 35.72 transiting M2

refsect2.title: Adding target to the queue
refsect2.para: One or multiple targets can be added to the queue with either queue command, or through rts2-xmlrpcd7 JSON interface, probably with help of the rts2-queue1. In this tutorial, we will consider adding target only directly, through queue executed in rts2-mon1.

Let's assume we would like to queue in targets 1000, 1001 and 1030 to the manual queue. For this, the following RTS2 command shall be entered in rts2-mon1.
queue manual 1000 1001 1030

refsect2.title: Night time operation
refsect2.para: During night, selector select targets for observation. rts2-executor7 then only executes observations selected by Selector.
Selector selects observational targets when the system is in night state. That state is active when Sun altitude is bellow night-horizon value specified in rts2.ini5.

When the system is either in dawn or dusk states, Selector select calibration observations. If Sun altitude is between flat_sun_min and flat_sun_max values, as specified in rts2.ini5. Otherwise, system will select dark target.

refsect1.title: Operation
refsect1.para: In order to allow selector operating correctly, the following conditions must be fullfilled:

listitem.para: must be on. Selector will not select next targets, if the system is in off or standby states.
shall be turned to true. Otherwise, the selector will select targets, but will not send them to the executor.
shall be turned to true. If turned to false, rts2-executor7 will not accept targets provided by &dhpackage;.

refsect2.title: Callibration observations
refsect2.para: In order to prepare callibration frames for a scientific data reduction, &dhpackage; allows two basic callibration observations to be scheduled during dusk and dawn. DARK FRAMES and/or SKYFLATS are acquired as needed.

refsect1.title: Variables
refsect1.variablelist:
&infotime;
next_id
ID of next target which should be observed. This is the target &dhpackage; suggest for selection.
next_plan_id
If next target is taken from the scheduler plan, containts its plan ID. Please see rts2-plan1 for details on plan management.
next_time
interrupt
idle_select
night_idle_select
selector_enabled
Enables selection of the next targets. If false, selector will not send next target IDs to executor.
flat_sun_min
Minimal sun altitute for scheduling flats observation. Flat observations will be ended at evening when Sun altitude drops bellow this value, and will start at morning once Sun altitude is above this value. Default value is taken from rts2.ini5 observatory section.
flat_sun_max
Maximal sun altitute for scheduling flats observation. Flat observations will start at evening when Sun altitude drops bellow this value, and will end at morning once Sun altitude is above this value. Default value is taken from rts2.ini5 observatory section.
night_disable_type
List types which should be disabled during the night. This is primarly intendet to disable flats during night. The value is taken from rts2.ini5, and default to "f F" to disable any targets of the flat type.
selector_queue
last_queue

refsect1.title: Queue variables
refsect1.para: Each selector queue provides a list of variables, visible in the rts2-mon1. Names of those variables start with name of the queue, followed with _ and the variable name. So for example, in the system with plan and manual queues, you will be able to find plan_ids and manual_ids variables.
Moreover, most of those queue variables are arrays. Entries of the array with the same index correspond to one queue entry.

listitem.para: Array of the targets IDs of the queue entries.

Number of repeats. Any value greater than 0 marks queue entry, which shall be repeated. Once the entry is observed, its rep_n is decreased by 1. If the rep_n value is greater than 0, the observation is placed at the end of the queue.

Interval between repeated observations. If the observations is repeated (its rep_n value is greater than 0), and rep_separation is set, its start time will be set to rep_separation seconds into future.

refsect1.title: RTS2 commands
refsect1.para: This sections describes extra commands available for &dhpackage;. Commands can be best executed from rts2-mon1.

refsect2.title: queue <queue name> <targets...>
refsect2.para: Queue target to the given queue. Queue name must be name of an existing queue. Targets are entered with their target ID. After adding all targets to the end of the queue, the queue is reordered according to its type - it is therefor possible, that the added targets will not end at the end of the queue.
